Detailed Description

Displays a wait cursor.

This class provides a way to show a wait cursor, which is usually displayed as an hourglass, while you are doing a lengthy operation.

Good Windows programming practices require that you display a wait cursor whenever you are performing an operation that takes a noticeable amount of time.

It is important that you do not do any message processing while doing the lengthy operation, as this will restore the cursor to its original shape.

Definition at line 1165 of file atlctrlx.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

WTL::CWaitCursor::CWaitCursor (  bool    bSet = true,
LPCTSTR    lpstrCursor = IDC_WAIT,
bool    bSys = true
)  [inline]
 

Constructor.

This constructor creates an instance of a CWaitCursor object. The default constructor automatically causes the wait cursor to be displayed.

Remarks:
When the object goes out of scope (at the end of the block in which the CWaitCursor object is declared), its destructor sets the cursor to the previous cursor. That is, the object performs the necessary clean-up automatically.
You can take advantage of the fact that the destructor is called at the end of the block (which might be before the end of the function) to make the wait cursor active in only part of your function. This technique is shown in the second example below.

Because of how their constructors and destructors work, CWaitCursor objects are always declared as local variables—they are never declared as global variables, nor are they allocated with new.

Parameters:
bSet  Set the wait cursor right away.
lpstrCursor  The cursor to use.
bSys  If non-zero then the lpstrCursor argument specifies a system cursor.
Note:
An example... 
void LengthyFunction()
{
   // wait cursor
   CWaitCursor wait;  // display wait cursor
   ...
   // destructor automatically removes the wait cursor
}

Restores old cursor.

Sets the original cursor.

Returns:
The value true if successful; otherwise, it returns false.

Definition at line 1199 of file atlctrlx.h.

bool WTL::CWaitCursor::Set (    )  [inline]
 

Sets the wait cursor.

This method restores the wait cursor after performing an operation, such as calling Restore or displaying a message box or dialog box, which might change the wait cursor to another cursor.

Note that the wait cursor is automatically set when the CWaitCursor object is created.

Returns:
The value true if successful; otherwise, it returns false.
